contentrichtext.text: {{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = Texas live oak |image = Texas Live Oak Quercus fusiformis.jpg |image_caption = An old Texas live oak at [[Alamo Mission in San Antonio|the Alamo]] |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fagales]] |familia = [[Fagaceae]] |genus = ''[[oak|Quercus]]'' |sectio = ''[[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|Quercus]]'' |series = ''[[Virentes]]'' |species = '''''Q. fusiformis''''' |binomial = ''Quercus fusiformis'' |}} '''''Quercus fusiformis''''' (also often referred to as ''Q. virginiana'' var. ''fusiformis''), commonly known as '''texas live oak''', '''escarpment live oak''', '''plateau live oak''', or '''plateau oak''', is an evergreen or nearly evergreen [[tree]]. Its native range includes the [[Quartz Mountains]] and [[Wichita Mountains]] in southwestern Oklahoma,<ref name="Oklahoma">{{cite web |url=http://www.biosurvey.ou.edu/shrub/qufu.htm |title=Quercus fusiformis |author=Bruce Hoagland |work=Oklahoma Biological Survey |publisher=Oklahoma Biological Survey |accessdate=October 10, 2012}}</ref> through Texas, to Coahuila, Tamaulipas, and Nuevo León in Mexico. This [[live oak]] in the [[white oaks|white oak section]] of the genus [[oak|''Quercus'']] is distinguished from [[Quercus virginiana]] (southern live oak) most easily by the [[acorn]]s, which are slightly larger and with a more pointed apex. It is also a smaller tree, not exceeding 1 m in trunk diameter (to 2.5 m diameter in southern live oak), with more erect branching and a less wide crown. Texas live oak is typically found on dry sites, unlike southern live oak, which prefers moister conditions. The tree is generally accepted to be the hardiest evergreen oak, able to withstand very cold winters with minimal leaf burn in areas as cold as [[Hardiness zone|USDA zone 6a]]. ==References== *{{Reflist}} *[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501031 Flora of North America - ''Quercus fusiformis''] *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=QUFU USDA Profile] *[http://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/ornamentals/natives/quercusfusiformis.htm Texas Native Plants Database] *[http://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=QUFU University of Texas at Austin] ==External links== * [http://wildflower.utexas.edu/plants/result.php?id_plant=QUFU Native Plant Information Network] More information on ''Quercus fusiformis'' [[Category:Quercus|fusiformis]] [[Category:Trees of Texas]] [[Category:Trees of Oklahoma]] [[Category:Trees of Northeastern Mexico]] [[Category:Trees of Coahuila]] [[Category:Trees of Nuevo León]] {{Fagales-stub}}
